column2: I've been figuring this out since I originally asked the question
column3: and I finally have a solution that does just what I want.  A bit of up front explanation is due
column4: however. IHttpHandler is a very basic interface:

column1: There is no built in property for accessing the route data
column2: and the route data also can't be found in the context or the request. A System.Web.UI.Page object has a RouteData property
column3: ServiceRoutes do all the work of interpreting your UriTemplates and passing the values to the correct method internally
column4: and ASP.NET MVC provides its own way of accessing the route data. Even if you had a RouteBase that (a) determined if the incoming url was a match for your route and (b) parsed the url to extract all of the individual values to be used from within your IHttpHandler
column5: there's no easy way to pass that route data to your IHttpHandler.  If you want to keep your IHttpHandler "pure"
column7: it takes responsibility for dealing with the url
column8: and how to extract any values from it. The RouteBase implementation in this case is only used to determine if your IHttpHandler should be used at all.

column2: however.  Once the RouteBase determines that the incoming url is a match for your route
column3: it passes off to an IRouteHandler
column4: which creates the instances of the IHttpHandler you want to handle your request.  But
column5: once you're in your IHttpHandler
column6: the value of context.Request.CurrentExecutionFilePath is misleading. It's the url that came from the client
column7: minus the query string.  So it's not the path to your .ashx file.  And
column8: any parts of your route that are constant (such as the name of the method) will be part of that execution file path value. This can be a problem if you use UriTemplates within your IHttpHandler to determine which specific method within your IHttpHandler should handing the request.

column1: Example: If you had a .ashx handler at /myApp/services/myHelloWorldHandler.ashx
And you had this route that mapped to the handler: "services/hello/{name}"
And you navigated to this url
column2: trying to call the SayHello(string name) method of your handler:

column1: Then your CurrentExecutionFilePath would be: /myApp/services/hello/Sam. It includes parts of the route url
column2: which is a problem. You want the execution file path to match your route url. The below implementations of RouteBase and IRouteHandler deal with this problem.
here's a very simple usage example.  Note that these implementations of RouteBase and IRouteHandler will actually work for IHttpHandlers that don't even have a .ashx file
column3: which is pretty convenient.

column1: That will cause all incoming urls that match the "services/headless" route to be handed off to a new instance of the HeadlessService IHttpHandler (HeadlessService is just an example in this case. It would be whatever IHttpHandler implementation you wanted to pass off to).

column2: so here are the routing class implementations
column3: comments and all:

column1: We have a situation with a fairly complex entity/table hierarchy modelled with EF4. Often we like most of the associations to load (whether lazy or not) and are happy with that.

Sometimes we want just the top of the hierarchy and maybe one or two of the related detail tables to be attached. For example when returning a set from a WCF method - as expected it will load every associated entity on the spot where often we just need a couple of them.

I know we can do this with projection but that seems to be a third slower than the regular query. I think we can also "clear()" the detail entity sets we do not want but that also would be a performance hit.
It seems crazy we can't pull the entity as normal and just prevent lazy loading from ocurring
column2: or prevent selected details from ever being attached. I think I am missing a simple thing.

column2: I would remove the copy constructor declaration. You have pure virtual functions so instances of this class can't be created by slicing in any case. If a derived class isn't copyable because of the nature of a resource that it holds; it can mark itself as non-copyable.

column1: Then I would get rid of the protected default constructor; it doesn't do anything and you have to derive from this class in any case as you have pure virtual functions so it's not preventing any usage.
Although marking the copy assignment operator prevents someone doing *pBase1 = *pBase2 (effectively a no-op)

column1: You'll notice the Posts table has a LastRevision field that is used as the increment for the post revisions. This is much better than computing the MAX each time you add a revision
column2: as it avoid a (range) scan of Revisions. It also acts as a concurrency protection: only one transaction at a time will be able to update it
column3: and only that transaction will proceed with inserting a new revision. Concurrent transactions will block and wait until the first one commits
column4: then the next transaction unblocked will correctly update the revision number to +1.

A variable is defined as a storage location. So the question is: does a storage location consume memory?
When you say it that way it sounds obvious that the answer is yes. What else would a storage location do other than consume memory?
It's not as simple as that. A local variable can consume no memory at all; a local variable might be enregistered by the jitter. In that case it would consume neither stack nor heap memory.
Why do you care? The way that the CLR manages memory to make storage locations for variables is an implementation detail. Unless you're writing unsafe code
column2: you don't have to worry about it.

the memory may already be reallocated and by executing delete again may cause memory corruption. The size of the block of memory allocated is often held just before the memory block itself.

do not call delete on the derived class (child). If it is not declared virtual then only the ~BaseClass() destructor is called leaving any allocated memory from the DerivedClass to persist and leak. This assumes that the DerivedClass has extra memory allocated above and beyond that of the BaseClass which must be freed.

column1: <pre><code>BaseClass* obj_ptr = new DerivedClass;  // Allowed due to polymorphism.
delete obj_ptr;  // this will call the destructor ~Parent() and NOT ~Child()

column1: The key difference between T-SQL and Win32 Filestream access is the way data is transferred to the client - using T-SQL to retrieve Filestream data means the storage engine must open the file on NTFS
column2: stream data back through the SQL engine and through TDS (the standard way SQL data is transferred) back to the client. If using Win32 the storage engine is still in the path during the open file operation however once this is complete the data can be transferred directly from the file to the client through Win32 streaming
column3: completely bypassing the SQL engine.

column1: As the blob size increases the overhead of opening the file and transferring through the engine becomes a smaller percentage of the total time required to complete the data transfer. Recent benchmarks for a very specific case study put the thresholds at 60KB for inline (varbinary max storage)
column2: 60KB-1.2MB for T-SQL transfer and >1.2MB for Win32 transfer. As I mentioned this was for a very specific case so YMMV.

column1: As far as security goes I can see a number of issues with using SQL security in this way
column2: but it's hard to offer suggestions without a little more context. You're really restricted from benefiting from Filestream by accessing it solely through T-SQL.

column1: To get characters from the terminal under UNIX-like operating systems (such as Linux)
column2: you read from STDIN (file number 0).  Normally
column3: the read system call will block until the user presses enter.  This is called canonical mode.  To read a single character without waiting for the user to press enter
column4: you must first disable canonical mode.  Of course
column5: you'll have to re-enable it if you want line input later on

column2: you send an IOCTL (IO ControL) to STDIN
column3: using the ioctl syscall. I assume you know how to make Linux system calls from assembler.

column1: The ioctl syscall has three parameters. The first is the file to send the command to (STDIN)
column2: the second is the IOCTL number
column3: and the third is typically a pointer to a data structure.  ioctl returns 0 on success
column4: or a negative error code on fail.

column1: The first IOCTL you need is TCGETS (number 0x5401) which gets the current terminal parameters in a termios structure. The third parameter is a pointer to a termios structure. From the kernel source
column2: the termios structure is defined as:
cc_t is one byte long
column3: and NCCS is currently defined as 19. See the NASM manual for how you can conveniently define and reserve space for structures like this.

column1: So once you've got the current termios
column2: you need to clear the canonical flag.  This flag is in the c_lflag field
column3: with mask ICANON (0x00000002).  To clear it
column4: compute c_lflag AND (NOT ICANON). and store the result back into the c_lflag field.

column1: Now you need to notify the kernel of your changes to the termios structure. Use the TCSETS (number 0x5402) ioctl
column2: with the third parameter set the the address of your termios structure.

the terminal is now in non-canonical mode. You can restore canonical mode by setting the canonical flag (by ORing c_lflag with ICANON) and calling the TCSETS ioctl again. always restore canonical mode before you exit
it isn't easy.

column1: Remember that the primary use of C++/CLI is for developing class libraries for consumption by GUIs / web services built in other .NET languages. So C++/CLI has to support both reference and value types because other .NET languages do.

column2: C# can have ref parameters that are value typed as well
column3: this isn't unique to C++/CLI and it doesn't in any way make value types equivalent to reference types.

column1: is this copy Disposable even though value types don't have destructors?
Incorrect. Value types can have destructors. Value types cannot have finalizers. Since this particular value type has a trivial destructor
column2: the C++/CLI compiler will not cause it to implement IDisposable.  In any case
column3: if a parameter is an IDisposable value type
column4: the C++/CLI compiler will ensure that Dispose is called when the variable goes out of scope
column5: just like stack semantics for local variables.  This includes abnormal termination (thrown exception)
column6: and allows managed types to be used with RAII.

column2: and put a boxed value type instance on the managed heap (which isn't a heap at all
column3: but a stack
column4: however it is not the call stack where local variables are stored
column5: so Microsoft chooses to call it a heap like the native memory area for dynamic allocation).

column2: C++/CLI can keep typed handles to boxed objects.

column1: If a tracking reference is to a value type instance on the stack or embedded in another object
column2: then the value type content has to be boxed in the process of formed the reference.

column1: Tracking references can also be used with reference types
column2: and the syntax to obtain a handle is the same:

column1: One thing that I can never seem to remember completely is that the syntax isn't 100% consistent compared to native C++.
DateTime% dtr = dt; // managed tracking reference

Note that the unary address-of operator is the same as the pointer notation in both standard C++ and C++/CLI. This seems to contradict a tracking reference cannot be used as a unary take-address operator (MSDN) which I'll get back to in a second.

column2: the inconsistency:

column1: Note that the unary dereference operator is always *. It is the same as the reference notation only in the native world
column2: which is completely opposite of references which
column3: as mentioned above
column4: are always the same symbol as the pointer notation.

column2: about unary address-of:
the MSDN article is wrong when it says:

column1: The following sample shows that a tracking reference cannot be used as a unary take-address operator.
% is the address-of operator for creation of a tracking handle. However its use is limited as follows:
A tracking handle must point to an object on the managed heap. Reference types always exist on the managed heap so there is no problem. However
column2: value types and native types may be on the stack (for local variables) or embedded within another object (member variables of value type).  Attempts to form a tracking handle will form a handle to a boxed copy of the variable: the handle is not linked to the original variable.  As a consequence of the boxing process
column3: which requires metadata which does not exist for native types
column4: it is never possible to have a tracking handle to an instance of a native type.

column1: // error C3071: operator '%' can only be applied to an instance
//              of a ref class or a value-type
If System::Int32 isn't a value type then I don't know what is. Let's try System::DateTime which is a non-primitive value type:

column2: primitive types which have dual identity (e.g. native int and managed value type System::Int32) are not handled correctly
column3: the % (form tracking reference) operator cannot perform boxing even when the .NET name for the type is given.

column1: The first is that xperf was actually using an older cached version of my symbols. This was fixed by deleting it from the symbol cache.
The second was that when I loaded symbols in xperfview
column2: it didn't actually put my up-to-date pdb into the symbols cache. The pdb was in a directory that I confirmed was included in the _NT_SYMBOL_PATH variable
column3: however. Unfortunately
column4: I don't remember the exact command used to fix this
column5: but I believe it was an 'xperf file.etl -symbols' variant. This command correctly parsed the etl and loaded/cached all of the relevant symbols as it encountered them. After this
column6: xperfview could correctly show my symbols.

column1: Note that I had to re-run the command any time my pdb changed
column2: because xperfview still wouldn't touch anything that wasn't already in the symbol cache. I'm still not sure why it behaves this way on my machine
column3: other people don't seem to have this problem.

column1: I've always felt that some types were naturally structs rather than classes
column2: yet could still have a few helper functions as members. The struct should still be POD by most of the usual rules - in particular it must be safe to copy using memcpy. It must have all member data public. But it still makes sense to me to have helper functions as members. I wouldn't even necessarily object to a private method
column3: though I don't recall ever doing this myself. And although it breaks the normal POD rules
column4: I wouldn't object to a struct having constructors
column5: provided they were just initialise-a-few-fields constructors (overriding assignment or destructors would definitely be against the rules).

column1: To me a struct is intuitively a collection of fields - a data structure node or whatever - whereas a class is an abstraction. The logical place to put the helper functions for your collection-of-fields may well be within the struct.
I even think I once read some advice along these lines
column2: though I don't remember where.

column1: EDIT - POD (Plain Old Data) is misrepresented by this question. In particular
column2: a struct can be non-POD purely because a member is non-POD - e.g. an aggregate with a member of type std::string. That aggregate must not be copied with memcpy. In case of confusion
column3: see here.

column1: 1 The fact that all parameters in the BizTalk XSLT are strings can be the source of a lot of gotchas - one other common one is with math calculations. If you return numeric values from your scripting functoids BizTalk will helpfully convert them to strings to map them to the outbound schema but will not so helpfully perform some very random rounding on the resulting values. Converting the return values to strings yourself within the C# will remove this risk and give you the expected results.

column2: the virtual machine is just another computer (implemented in software instead of hardware).
lots of commercial apps will blow up when you run them on a VM due to:
using undocumented features of BIOS/Kernel/hardware

a VM is just another computer consisting of hardware implemented in assembly instead of circuits/dye/microcode/magic. This means the VM must provide the emulated hardware either through pass-through or emulation. The fact that hardware is very diverse can cause all kinds of different behavior. Also note the possible lack of drivers for or acceleration of the emulated hardware.

column1: But of course a typical business application for example isn't nearly as likely to rely on any hardware details as all it does is call some GUI API.

column1: I would look into clustering the web end immediately and use that as your primary scaling mechanism. 30k connections is quite a lot and you don't have much room for growth before you hit a server limit of some kind. If the I/O itself isn't onerous I would just use lots of threads and servers with lots of horsepower and memory. Get it working that way so you can ship
column2: and have a fallback plan to switch to multiplexed NIO if performance or scaling becomes a problem
column3: but be warned that it's a radical overhaul and about ten times as complex to program as java.net. After several years' consideration I am more and more wondering whether NIO to economize on threads is really worth it: it adds several new problems of its own such as a need for push parsing; synchronization issues with the selector if there are worker threads that need to change the registration state of channels; lots of ways to get the code wrong; and the fact that the scheduling overhead moves out of the OS into your application
column4: where you only have linear set-iterator data structures to deal with it unless you engage in yet another level of complexity. It's worth remembering that select() was invented for Unix to allow economizing on processes
column5: which are expensive. Threads are pretty cheap really
column6: and provide a very simple programming model with built-in context for handling a single connection. NIO barely manages this at all except via disciplined use of selection key attachments

column2: I was asked to submit several code samples that highlight my "best" work. I was pinged back with several questions regarding a specific code sample
column3: one of which alluded to a bug.

column1: The code sample was a WCF Web service that uses AES to encrypt an opaque blob. The blob is used by the service to identify all resources for a specific service request. The bug was that the .NET RijndaelManaged class was used with CBC mode
column2: without properly setting the IV. The RijndaelManaged class will autogenerate an appropriate IV during class instantiation
column3: which in the code sample
column4: occurs during first usage of encryption
column5: and is persisted for the life of the ASP .NET Application. Since ASP.NET applications can be restarted for a variety of reasons
column6: it's possible that a these opaque blobs would be "invalidated" from one service call to the next because of a new IV value generated during App startup (the bug).

column1: The question itself was "where is IV set for decryption?"
My response is already to admit that this is a bug; but since they asked for my "best" work
column2: am I SOL on this position for having submitted a sample with a bug? Is there more I can say?

column1: I'm hesitant to outline the situation because I don't want to seem like I'm making an excuse
column2: but the encryption code was turned off while our service was in pre-alpha
column3: and the project was killed before we ever went into production.

column3: then this is the normal behavior as typically the application will launch and only then call the function you have (applicationDidFinishLaunching). There is no guarantee that you will get that function called before the controls have loaded and are viewable on the screen all the time.

column1: It is bad form to start you application with a movie
column2: but if you want to then you have to deal with the fact that there will potentially be a default image or even your controls that you put in your XIB file.

column1: One way to start with a movie
column2: is that you must hide or delete everything in the XIB file so the screen will appear blank when the application loads. Then
column3: when you application calls the applicationDidFinishLaunching function the user will not have seen your application and the first thing they will see is the movie. When the movie is finished playing
column4: you will need to have a notification listener instruct your application to show the controls for your application or switch to another XIB file that has the app controls within it.

column1: My workplace uses Hudson for its daily builds
column2: with several build slaves (one Linux
column3: one Windows
column4: one Mac) checking out our full codebase from svn and building our app at midnight each day. This all works fairly well.

column1: There is an occasional problem that happens though... sometimes a developer will be working late
column2: and will check in a change to svn just after midnight.  When this occurs
column3: it's possible that some of the daily build slaves will do their 'svn checkout' before the svn commit is processed
column4: while other build slaves will do it after the commit is processed.  When this happens
column5: we end up with different revisions built on different platforms... e.g. the Mac build might a build of SVN revision 5555
column6: while the Windows build ends up being a build of SVN revision 5556.  That's bad
column7: since we want all of the daily builds for a given day to be based on the same codebase.

column1: I suppose one way to avoid this is to forbid developers to commit to svn between 11:30PM and 12:30AM
column2: but I'd prefer a more elegant solution that doesn't rely on the developers behavior.  Is there one?  In particular
column3: if there is a way to tell hudson to check out the revision of the code that was current at midnight of the current day (e.g. "svn co -r{"the-current-date"}") instead of checking out HEAD
column4: I think that might do the trick.

column1: After competing in and following this year's Google Code Jam competition
column2: I couldn't help but notice the incredible number of [successful] contestants that used C/C++ and Java. The distribution of languages used throughout the competition can be seen here.

column1: After programming in C/C++ for several years
column2: I recently fell in love with Python for its readable/straightforward nature. More recently
column3: I learned functional languages like OCaml
column4: Scheme
column5: and even logic languages like Prolog. These languages certainly have their merits and
column7: can be applied more easily than C++ and Java for certain situations. For example
column8: Scheme's use of call/cc simplifies backtracking (a tool required to answer several problems) and Prolog's logic specification
column9: although inefficient due to its brute-force nature
column10: can drastically simplify (and even automatically solve) certain problems that are difficult to wrap one's brain around.

column1: It is clear that a competition contestant should use the tools that are best suited for the challenge. Even x86 assembly is Turing complete - that doesn't justify solving problems with it. In this case
column2: <strong>why are the contestants that use less common languages like Scheme/Lisp
column3: Prolog
column4: and even Python significantly less successful than contestants that use C/C++ and Java? Worded differently
column5: <strong>why don't successful contestants use languages that
column7: are arguably better tools for the job?

column1: There are several motivations for my question. Most importantly
column2: I would like to become a better programmer - both in the practical aspect and the competition aspect. After being introduced to such beautiful paradigms like functional and logic programming
column3: it is discouraging to see so many people discard them in favor of C/C++ and Java. It even makes me question my admiration for said paradigms
column4: worrying that I cannot be successful as a Lisp/Scheme/Prolog programmer in a programming competition.

I want to extend the asp.net validators such that I can make one validator dependent on another. The situation I have is that we have to validate a date in a textbox. Normally I would just use a combination of a RequiredFieldValidator (to ensure the date is provided)
column2: CompareValidator (to ensure the date is a date) and finally a RangeValidator (to ensure the date is within the required limit).

column1: The problem with this is that the validators do not depend on each other
column2: so as a result the user would see possibly all three messages at once for each validator when really all we want them to see is the most relevant message
column3: i.e. if they entered "abc" in the date text box it would not be appropriate to show them the message saying the date was not in the valid range (even though technically I suppose this is true).

column1: Currently to provide this kind of functionality we use a CustomValidator and just put all three validations within the server validate event handler and change the error message programmatically depending on what validation failed.
I would like to standardize this a bit more as it happens quite a bit in this application
column2: I figure if I can make the validators dependent on each other this will solve the problem and also allow us to make use of the client side validation rather than having to do a postback especially to handle the custom validation.

column1: The idea is that if one validator is dependent on another if that "master" is valid then the depended will perform its normal validation (EvaluateIsValid()) otherwise if the master validator is not valid then the other dependent validators will be valid.
I have come up with the following solution by inheriting from the various validator controls that already have been provided in the framework.
[Description("The validation control to depend on for determining if validation should occur")]
throw new HttpException("ValidationControlToDependOn is not a validation control");
Currently I have just coded it for the RequiredFieldValidator
column2: ideally I would like to provide this functionality for all of the validators but I cannot see a way to do this without copying the above code into a similar class for each individual type of validator I want to provide this functionality for thus if there are any problems I'm going to have to go back and change this code on each validator type individually.

column1: Is there a way I can "centralise" this code and have it easily used in the validators without having to write the entire validators from scratch just so I can change the class they inherit from further down the line.

Why Java impl choose merge sort over quick sort? and why do they copy the content to an array?

API: "The sorting algorithm is a modified mergesort (in which the merge is omitted if the highest element in the low sublist is less than the lowest element in the high sublist). This algorithm offers guaranteed n log(n) performance. This implementation dumps the specified list into an array
column2: sorts the array
column3: and iterates over the list resetting each element from the corresponding position in the array. This avoids the n2 log(n) performance that would result from attempting to sort a linked list in place."

column1: People often realloc to twice the existing size to get amortized constant time instead of linear. This makes the buffer no more than twice as large
column2: which is usually okay
column3: and you have the option of reallocating back down to the correct size after you're done.

column1: But even better is to stat(2) for the file size and allocate once (with some extra room if the file size is volatile).

column3: or
column4: even better

column1: [Let's get the standard disclaimer out of the way: contest programming is only loosely related to "programming in the real world"
column2: and while it tests algorithmic and problem-solving skills and the ability to come up with fast bug-free working code under time pressure
column3: it does not necessarily correlate with being able to build large software projects
column4: write maintainable code
column5: etc (beyond the fact that well-structured programs are easier to debug).]

column1: • C++/Java are more common than other languages in the real world as well
column2: so you'd expect to see a higher proportion anywhere. (But it's even higher in the contest population.)
or got into contests as students
column3: and C++/Java are more common "first languages" that students learn. (Undergrad students these days may start with Scheme
column4: Haskell
column5: Python
column7: but high-schoolers (often self-taught) less often.) In fact
column8: many of the Eastern European participants still use Pascal
column9: and are more amazing with it than the rest of us will ever be with any language.

column1: • The school- and college-level contests usually use these languages. The International Olympiad in Informatics (IOI) allows only C
column2: C++ and Pascal (or maybe it allows Java now; I haven't kept up)
column3: and the ACM Intercollegiate Programming Contest (ACM ICPC) allows only C
column4: C++ and Java. TopCoder allows C++
column5: Java
column7: Python. So you could say the "contest ecosystem" has more C++/Java programmers in it. Google Code Jam and IPSC are among the few contests that allow code in any language

column2: in GCJ where the contestants are free to choose a language
column3: why wouldn't they choose Python or Scheme? The most relevant factor is that these languages are slow. Sure
column4: for most real-world programming they are easily fast enough
column5: but for the tight loops that are often involved in getting a program to run under the n-second limit for all test cases
column6: these languages don't cut it for any of the algorithmically more involved problems. (A problem designed to accept O(n log n) solutions but not Θ(n2) solutions for C/C++ frequently rules out even optimal O(n log n) solutions in slower languages. Even Java used to be given a handicap at USACO; I'm not sure this is still the case.)

column1: • Another factor is the libraries: C++ and Java have better libraries for frequently useful algorithms and data structures (e.g. red-black trees
column2: C++'s next_permutation)
column3: while Python's libraries (good enough for the real world) are less useful here
column4: and Prolog and Scheme... I don't know about their libraries. This is a relatively minor factor
column5: because these programmers can write their own code when necessary. :-)

column1: • General-purpose multi-paradigm languages are more useful for just getting things done within the time constraints of the contest
column2: than languages that force a philosophy or way of doing things on you. This is why Prolog will always remain unpopular
column3: for instance. (General philosophy: some languages are "enabling" languages that let you do anything including shooting yourself in the foot
column4: some are "directing" that force you to do things the right way.) This is also why C++ is three times more popular than Java in the general contest participants
column5: and much more popular among the top contestants. Since code doesn't have to be read by anyone else
column6: it's ok and even useful to have loop macros like <code>FOR(i
column8: and more importantly less chance of making a bug when in a hurry). Nothing against Java
column9: there are a few top programmers who use Java too. :-)

column2: although many of these top programmers may have C++/Java/Pascal as their "first language"
column3: they are not good because of their language
column4: so you don't have to despair about that. Many of these same programmers have won contests like the ICFP contest even with intentionally using crazy languages like shell scripts

column6: and assembly (the team named "You Can't Spell Awesome Without ASM").

column2: "it depends on what you're doing" But since you asked
column3: start here:

column2: IronPython is essentially the same as C# with a little different syntax -- I know
column3: its a sweeping generalization for two languages with wholly dissimilar type systems
column4: but they're no much else I can say about yet another imperative
column5: OO language. Whether its C#
column9: you solve languages using roughly the same techniques
column14: you've almost certainly worked with C# or VB.NET
column15: and you've already been writing code in an imperative style for as long as you've been using the languages.

column1: The biggest point in favor of F# is simply that it encourages more functional programming styles
column2: downplays abstractions through OO inheritance in favor of function composition
column3: immutability as a default instead of as an after thought
column4: and so on. If you want to write functional code
column5: you need to use a functional language.

column2: you can write functional style in C# and Python
column3: but functional features are grafted on as an afterthought. Python lacks multiline lambdas
column4: and C# is too verbose and occasionally buggy to make use of functional style in the places where you want to use it
column5: C# in particular has a whole boatload of gotchas regarding delegates and capturing local variables
column6: both languages lack tail-call optimizations almost everywhere that you'd want to use them
column7: C#'s type inference is a joke compared to F#. I've tried using C# as a functional language with hilariously bad results :)

column1: Now most people might concede that problems make it difficult
column2: but not impossible to program in a functional style using C# or Python. However
column3: in my experience
column4: its not the languages that make it impossible
column5: its the programmers on your team. If you've got 10 or 12 people writing code in an imperative language
column6: you won't be able to enforce a functional style for very long -- the languages don't do anything to discourage imperative style. And since programmers already code in that style
column7: that's what you get. Unless you have some really hardcore and slightly masochistic FP enthusiasts on your team
column8: I don't think could enforce a purely functional programming style in an imperative language for very long.

column1: The best argument in favor of F# isn't necessarily functional programming itself
column2: but really diversity of your toolset. You get a bigger ROI pairing up F# and C# (different programming paradigm and similar type system) than pairing up IronPython and C# (same programming paradigm and different type system).
so with that being said
column3: I've been trying to push for F# at my company. I won't go into a huge amount of detail on what we do
column4: but essentially my team guides users through the process of ordering cable and phone services for companies like Time Warner
column5: ComCast

column1: Its really a more involved process than it sounds. For a start
column2: there is a complicated rules engine which determines availability of products
column3: dependencies and exclusions between products
column4: etc. We walk the rule engine graph and build a decision tree out of it
column5: then we hand the tree to a client so they can display it to the user and collect user input
column6: client maps GUI back to our decision tree structure
column7: we walk the tree and validate everything against the rules engine

column1: I'd say 95% of our code is simply navigating
column2: manipulating
column3: and processing tree-like data structures. Right now
column4: everything we write is C# and its kind of a mess. Incidentally
column5: one of F#'s strengths is manipulating ASTs and symbolic processing (see a comparison of C# and F# code for processing ASTs)
column6: and its all possible because pattern matching is awesome.

column1: Pattern matching is a real killer feature
column2: its exactly what our C# code needs to clean it up
column3: and that's why we need F#. We don't have any use for IronPython because its no better at symbolic processing than C#.

column1: Functional programming paradigm and pattern matching are two killer features I enjoy with F# everyday. I could go about F#'s async threading model
column2: message passing concurrency primitives
column3: support of monads
column4: novel features like active patterns
column5: and so on
column6: but those are all bullet point comments. For me
column7: its those two killer features that make the case for F# over Python -- at least for my own projects.

column2: in order to understand why this might happened we need to look at the different options for adding files to xcode.

column1: When you're adding a file to xcode you are presented with a dialog that includes a few interesting and sometimes overlooked option.
The first - Should the file be copied to the project folder
column2: or should it just point to the file original location. The safest way will be to always copy the files to the project's path. However for images (such in your case) I do it differently. I maintain a separate graphics folder for every app
column3: I save images there (both sources
column4: and final png). When I add an image I do not copy it to the project folder
column5: rather xcode just points to its location. That way I can just edit the image in photoshop
column7: and the updated image will show up on the phone. Whats important to understand that the directory structure of files you include in the project have almost no meaning
column8: files that appear in the Copy Bundle Resources for the target will always be copied to a single (and flat) bundle/"directory" on the phone. The only exception for this is if you actually add directories to xcode (Personally I recommend against it).

column2: is to which targets to add the file. This is the list with checkboxes on the bottom
column3: if when you added the image
column4: your app target wasn't checked the file won't be included in the target Copy bundle resource
column5: and won't be available for the phone.

column1: A few caveats - When using references to files in other location
column2: that location is relative to the project's path
column3: so it's a good idea to keep all the files in directories below the project's root directory. That way you can still copy the entire project to a different location and it will still work.

column1: There are a couple of problems in you script:
Upon setting up the choose folder variables you have to put parentheses around choose folder in order to force the Finder to convert the alias returned by choose folder to an object specifier:
The loop that moves the items will terminate with an index out of bounds error because the number of items in the originFolder changes upon each iteration through the loop
column2: as items are being moved.

column1: A better solution is to first compute the indexes of the files that should be moved and then have the Finder perform the move operation in one step:
repeat with i from 4 to (count of items in originFolder) by 4
copy i to end of indexes
move (every item of originFolder whose index is in indexes) to destFolder

column1: Apps can receive and respond to location events in the background in two ways:

• An application can declare itself as a continuous background location application (full-time background processing in response to all location events).

column1: I still do the same because I've never been convinced of the value of using it as a form of documentation. If you need to convey that an object only has public members

column4: but this time you're all by yourself to choose the right texture and compute the UVs.

column1: The two main differences between F# and Iron Python are:

column2: while Iron Python is not.

column1: • The foundation of F# is functional programming while the foundation of Iron Python is object-oriented programming. (With both having good support for other-paradigms.)

column2: and they directly lead to the main practical reasons to prefer one over the other.
Iron Python is slower than F# due to the lack of static typing.  In the Computer Language Benchmarks
column3: Iron Python is 25x in the median
column4: and 120x slower in the worst case.  So if runtime performance is a consideration
column5: F# is likely preferable.

column2: each can use the libraries of the other with just a little work.  So I don't see this as a major issue
column3: although I guess it's possible to use SciPy in IronPython
column4: while it would be tedious from F#
column5: and the corresponding best free library for F# isn't quite as good.

column1: Functional programming can be a very powerful style
column2: and allows F# to have some powerful features like workflows
column3: including asynchronous workflows which are well supported by the F# libraries.  You could roughly emulate such things in Iron Python
column4: but it wouldn't work quite as smoothly
column5: in part because of lack of support in the libraries.

column1: Object orientation is more familiar to many programmers
column2: and they might prefer Python for that reason.

column1: Static typing also allows an IDE to provide better support to programmers. The type of each variable can be reported to the programmer (via hovering in VS)
column2: and feedback on errors can be given while the code is being edited. As a university lecturer I can say that this immediate feedback is extremely useful to my students while they are learning F#. This enables them to manage more complex programs than they could otherwise.
simple programs to be written slightly more quickly.  If this is the only coding you'll be doing then Python may be preferable.  But
column3: if there's a chance a program will grow into something larger
column4: then I'd prefer F#.

column1: • Be especially careful with the right hand side of an integer division/remainder operations
• Arithmetic overflow/underflow DOES NOT cause an exception to be thrown
• Loss of precision DOES NOT cause an exception to be thrown
• A mathematically indefinite floating point operation DOES NOT cause an exception to be thrown
• Division and remainder operations throws ArithmeticException if the right hand side is zero

column1: The general rule for all floating point operation is as follows:
• An operation that overflows produces a signed infinity.
• An operation that underflows produces a denormalized value or a signed zero.
• An operation that has no mathematically definite result produces NaN.
• All numeric operations with NaN as an operand produce NaN as a result.

column1: • Keep all third-party libraries in a separate source control repository

column1: Basically the designers know how quickly you can gather resources (both the best case and the average case)
column2: and they know how long it takes to build a unit
column3: and they know roughly how powerful a unit is (eg. by reference to approximations such as damage per second). With this
column4: you can ensure a unit's cost in resources makes sense. And from that
column5: it's possible to compare resource gathering with unit cost to model the strength of a force growing over time. Similarly you can measure a force's capacity for damage over time
column6: and compare the two. If there's a big disparity then they can tweak one or more of the variables to reduce it. Obviously there are many permutations of units but the interesting thing is that you only really need to understand the most powerful permutations - if a player picks a poor combination then it's ok if they lose. You don't want every approach to be equally good
column7: as that would imply a boring game where your decisions are meaningless.

column2: of course
column3: a simplification
column4: but it helps get everything in roughly the right place and ensure that there are no units that are useless. Then testing can hammer down the rough edges and find most of the exploits that remain.

column1: Because of the existence of data binding
column2: I make sure the only code that can update business objects is code that's running on the GUI thread.
I adopt a pattern of:

column1: • Send work to the background: Trigger an async operation -- say
column2: a thread pool item -- from the GUI thread. Pass only plain data types into the thread pool
column3: and receive only plain data types back. If business objects are used by the thread pool
column4: make sure that these are either brand new ones (that haven't been data bound yet)
column5: or are clones of the originals (to avoid concurrent access)

column1: • Do the work and obtain a result: Execute the async operation on a background thread. The background thread code will own the 'safe' objects given to it by the GUI; it won't have any interaction with the rest of the application.
• Unpack the result in the GUI: When the async operation is finished
column2: it triggers an 'I am complete' event on the GUI thread. In response
column3: the GUI thread can unpackage any results from the background operation and merge them back into the main business objects
column4: safe in the knowledge that it won't be dealing with concurrent access.

column1: I can recommend the System.Threading.Tasks.Task class as an abstraction around most of the above steps. It's new in .NET 4.0
column2: but it's also available as a separate download for .NET 3.5 apps.

column1: Steps (1) and (2) are what the Task class does without any customisation. You can achieve (3) by spawning a separate Task from inside the background thread and specifying TaskScheduler.FromCurrentSynchronizationContext as a scheduler. (You'll need to call FromCurrentSynchronizationContext from the GUI thread
column2: in step (1)
column3: not from the background thread.)

column1: There are a number of ways of reducing DNS load time with different host names. One trick is to have the other host names in the AR section of the DNS response; for example
column2: if someone asks for a.example.com
column3: we can helpfully tell them the DNS hostnames for b.example.com
column4: c.example.com
column5: d.example.com
column6: and so on as additional records in the DNS reply
column7: when giving them the IP for a.example.com in the answer.

column1: This will pre-cache the answers for all of those other host names with some
column2: but not all
column3: recursive DNS servers (for security reasons
column4: this trick doesn't work for either of the recursive DNS servers I have implemented
column5: since
column7: they do not blindly cache records in the AR section of a DNS reply).

column1: Another trick to minimize DNS lookups is to have all of the names in the same domain (have all names end in
column2: for example
column3: example.com: a.example.com
column4: b.example.com
column5: etc.)
column6: make sure no glueless records need to be followed to resolve the names (make your NS records have names like ns1.example.com and ns2.example.com
column7: and don't use any CNAME entries)
column9: if your servers do not change IPs very often
column10: have a large TTL for the DNS entries for your servers.

I don't most of your points are correct.
• there is no hash map in the current standard. C++0x introduces unordered_map
column2: who's implementation will be a hash table and your compiler probably already supports it.

column1: • std::map is implemented as a balanced tree
column2: not  a hash table. There are no "memory issues" when using either map type with strings
column3: either as keys or data.

column1: • strings are not stored as numbers in either case - an unordered_map will use a hashing function to derive a numeric key from the string
column2: but this is not stored.

column1: • my experience is that unordered_map is about twice the speed of map - they have basically the same interface
column2: so you can try both with your own data - whenever you are interested in performance you should always perform tests your self with your own real data
column3: rather than depending on the experience of others. Both map types will be somewhat sensitive to the length of the string key.

column1: To me a more general way is via a monad/comonad pair. This generalizes the common "monad" approach which should correctly be called the "strong monad" approach
column2: since it only works with strong monads.

column1: Moving to a monad/comonad pair allows effects to be modeled that result in some variables no longer being available. An example where this is useful is the effect of migrating a thread to another host in a distributed setting.

An additional method of historical interest is to make the whole program a function mapping a stream/list of input events to a stream/list of output events. See: "How to Declare an Imperative" by Phil Wadler: http://www.cs.bell-labs.com/~wadler/topics/monads.html#monadsdeclare

column1: A modal view controller pops up from the bottom of the screen and displays its own view. When this view is dismissed
column2: it shuffles down and disappears.
a modal controller is a good place for a transient authentication screen — you just bring it in view
column3: the user enters his or her info
column4: and the view is dismissed.

column1: On returning to the parent view controller
column2: it checks the authentication credentials and modifies its view if authenticated (or not).

column1: Another advantage of the modal view controller is that it is on its own navigation stack. So you don't need to push a controller
column2: pop up and then push a different view controller. It makes for cleaner code and a cleaner interface (again

column1: The basic principle is that each recursive call to permute successively places each remaining element at position d; the element that was at position d is saved by putting it where the aforementioned remaining element was (i.e. the elements are swapped). For each placement
column2: permute is called recursively to generate all desired substrings after the position d. So the top-level call (d=0) to permute successively tries all elements in position 0
column3: second-level calls (d=1) try all elements in position 1 except for the one that's already in position 0
column4: etc. The next-to-deepest calls (d=n-1) have a single element to try in the last position
column5: and the deepest calls (d=n) print the resulting permutation.

column1: The core algorithm requires Θ(n·n!) running time
column2: which is the best possible since that's the size of the output. However this implementation is less efficient that it could be because it recomputes strlen(s) at every iteration
column3: for a Θ(n²·n!) running time; the simple fix of precomputing the length would yield Θ(n·n!). The implementation requires Θ(n) memory
column4: which is the best possible since that's the size of the input.

There are two primary things I've written regarding IDisposable
column2: and I recommend you read at least the first one: How to Implement IDisposable and Finalizers - 3 Easy Rules (I also have other blog posts on the subject) and IDisposable - What Your Mother Never Told You about Resource Deallocation.

column1: When SHOULD I use IDisposable? Only when I have unmanaged resources?
IDisposable should be used for one of three things: freeing an unmanaged resource
column2: freeing managed resources
column3: and RAII. I prefer to use different patterns for these different needs.

column1: Note that the rest of my answers (and the links) are all discussing IDisposable in the context of freeing resources. They don't address RAII.
What variations of the dispose pattern are there and why do they vary?
The Microsoft pattern is the most well-known. It handles freeing unmanaged and managed resources and allowing for inheritance. I prefer a simpler pattern described on my blog (3 easy rules)
column2: which is the pattern that Microsoft has actually followed since .NET 2.0.

column1: What are common unmanaged resources I should be aware of?
My preference is to have a single IDisposable class for each type of unmanaged resource (akin to Microsoft's SafeFileHandle). So
column2: any time you add a type of unmanaged resource to your program/library
column3: you only have to handle it once.

column1: The question then becomes "which classes should I dispose?"
column2: which has a simple answer: "all classes that implement IDisposable."

column1: Is it ever wrong or misleading to implement IDisposable?
No. An empty IDisposable implementation is always an option. You should consider adding IDisposable to interfaces or base classes if you think an implementation may use them. This is a design issue
column2: which I discuss more in my What Your Mother Never Told You article.

column1: Should Dispose calls ever be chained together
column2: or should we rely on using statements?

column1: It's common for Dispose to call Dispose on all member objects that it owns. See my second rule blog post for more details.

column1: That means precisely what is says. When an application for your OS is being linked
column2: the crt0 must be the very first object file on linker's command line: before any other object file.

UNIX linkers resolve a symbol by making a look up starting from first object/library looping over to the last object/library. Putting crt0 as the first object file makes sure that system symbols (functions
column3: variables) are picked from the crt0 file
column4: not some other file.

column2: as pointed by R..
column3: traditional linkers assume that application's entry point is at the beginning of the code segment. That also fits to the source code found on the linked page: first symbol in the code is _start
column4: the usual name of the program's entry point.

column1: E.g. running gcc -v a.c -o a on my Debian (notice the -v)
column2: one sees following linking command (I have added new lines for readability):

column1: One can see that crt1 is first object on the command line. Looking at the linker script (-m elf_i386 -> find /usr -name '*elf_i386*' -> on my system /usr/lib/ldscripts/elf_i386.x) one can verify that on Linux there is no crt0
column2: but there are: crt1
column3: crti
column4: crtbegin
column5: crtend
column6: crtn. And the application object files (/tmp/ccndJ4YV.o in the sample above) are put between the crtbegin and crtend.

column1: 1) Specify what class the callback is going to use
column2: so that the object pointer and member function pointer types are known

column4: which you can choose between
column5: but your options are quite limited.

column1: One thing that you've done wrong in your code is that member function pointers and free function pointers in C++ are not the same
column2: and are not compatible types. Your callback registration function takes a function pointer
column3: but you're trying to pass it a member function pointer. Not allowed. Furthermore
column4: the type of the "this" object is part of the type of a member function pointer
column5: so there's no such thing in C++ as "a pointer to any member function which takes an integer and returns void". It has to be
column6: "a pointer to any member function of Target which takes an integer and returns void". Hence the limited options.

column1: 2) Define a pure virtual function in an interface class. Any class which wants to receive the callback therefore can inherit from the interface class. Thanks to multiple inheritance
column2: this doesn't interfere with the rest of your class hierarchy. This is almost exactly the same as defining an Interface in Java.

column1: 3) Use a non-member function for the callback. The for each class which wants to use it
column2: you write a little stub free function which takes the object pointer and calls the right member function on it. So in your case you'd have:
int a) {

column1: I use around 1000 properties associated with a specific java.util.Properties which is backed by a file. The main reason for the file is to change them without recompiling the program and to allow users to adjust their according to their taste.
Some of the properties are used only in one place in the code
column2: but there are some properties that are used several times in different segments of code and even different classes.

column1: I have recently got the habit of declaring all those properties that are used as a String constants
column2: usually in a seperate interface like this:

column1: When a class need to access some of the animal properties
column2: I just implement this interface and I have access to all those property constants declared. When I need a specific property I just use the corresponding constant
column3: without thinking what is its exact name (since abbreviations are used often) and
column4: what is more important
column5: the risk of mistyping a property name is eliminated this way. Another advantage is that if I later choose to rename a property to make it more clear to the advanced user who configures those properties)
column6: I just need to change that name in the interface where that property constant is declared (and of course the property file)
column7: so no need to "search and replace" the entire project. Finally
column8: I can easily check whether the property is being used or not; I just comment it
column9: compile the code and see if there is an error.

column2: in spite of all these advantages
column3: I am curious what are the disadvantages of this approach. What interests me the most is the following:

column1: • What impact has this approach (1000 String constants) on the String pool? Or they are created on-demand when I access those constants? Does this prevent other Strings from being cached in the String pool?
<li>What is the performance cost of this approach compared to the one where I use hard-coded String constants
column2: is it the same (neglecting the cost of accessing field)? Does the String pool behave similarly or a lot different?

column1: <li>What's the average memory increase with this approach
column2: are all those String constants kept in memory all the time?

column1: I don't think that the registry is a good place to hide such info
column2: because anyone can download and use the Process Monitor (http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/bb896645.aspx) tool and see what your program does with the registry.

column1: And thinking about this again. You will probably make users of your software unhappy if it will leave things in registry and other "secret" places on the user's hard drive. Locations like that are also easily discovered by tools that monitor what system functions your software calls.

As an alternative you could embed the banned keys in your application when you release new versions. This way the banned keys will be hidden in the application making it much harder for crackers to bypass the protection.
The downside of this is that a user can potentially run older version with a banned key with internet access blocked to your site
column2: but if your software is actively developed with new features and bugfixes added
column3: then nobody would want to run older versions. And if you are very paranoid you could release "updates" which update just the embedded banned key list.

column1: But in the end no software protection scheme is perfect. If your software is popular enough there will always be a pirate cracker who will figure out your protection and make a patch or even a key generator.

You can't. Don't believe those swf protector/encryptors. Both the content of a swf and a swc need to be readable by the AVM2 so it can't be compressed or encrypted or anything. Bottom line is that you can't really protect your as3 code from being reverse engineered.

column2: we have a number of systems behind a portal. Customers can access the portal and
column3: based on their permissions they can access features of each different application. In the current scenario
column4: we may have a single authentication step (user id/password) that passes the authorised identity/principal (against a custom authentication store) to each application. The application then uses this pre-authenticated identity to look up against its own roles to allow users access to certain features.

column1: This is all managed internally - i.e. each application understands its own roles so each application has its own admin function that maps a user to a role.

column2: so it works but is a pain to manage and our customer has to remember our portal user id and password.

column1: I'd like to move to a trusted environment so that we trust the token from their STS and authentication is all hidden. However
column2: I simply cannot see how Authorisation will work - we're asking that each third party implement roles in their STS to pass along with the token. We've shifted the admin to them which may break their security models anyway.

column1: So we cannot delegate authorisation to them
column2: and still need to manage the map of a trusted token to the roles the application requires.

column1: So the great benefit of trusted STS
column2: whereby user A leaves trusted company 123 and user B joins to take over
column3: and they don't have to wait for us to make any changes..... just isn't practical in the real world.

column2: there are three models.

column1: The traditional form model uses form postbacks for every action that requires going to the server
column2: and may use javascript to perform client-side tasks that make the user's life easier without compromising security (e.g. pre-postback validation). The advantage of this is that such a web application
column3: if written correctly
column4: will work without needing any javascript at all
column5: and it is easier to make it work on a wide range of devices (e.g. audio browsers).

column1: The server-centric ajax model uses ajax calls to provide partial page refreshes; the page is built like in the traditional model
column2: but instead of triggering a full page post-back
column3: client-side script uses ajax calls to send clicks and other events
column4: and retrieves information to replace a part of the document (usually in JSON or XHTML form). Because you don't post the entire page every time
column5: the response is usually quicker. This model is useful if you want to use ajax where possible
column6: but still want to be able to fall back to traditional postbacks if javascript isn't available.

column1: Client-centric ajax takes a different path; the core idea is that you write your entire application in javascript
column2: using ajax to exchange data
column3: not markup. When you click a button
column4: the application sends a request to the server
column5: and receives data. The data is then used for further processing on the client. This is more flexible and usually faster than the other methods
column6: but it requires good knowledge of javascript. Applications written in this style generally don't work at all when javascript is disabled on the client.

column1: Static fields are are initialized during the initialization phase during class loading.
But if a primitive type or a String is defined as a constant and the value is known at compile time
column2: the compiler replaces the constant name everywhere in the code with its value. This is called a compile-time constant. If the value of the constant in the outside world changes (for example
column3: if it is legislated that pi actually should be 3.975)
column4: you will need to recompile any classes that use this constant to get the current value.

column1: This is when String Literals for unique string's will be created which are defined as values of constants.
But it is similar as loading constants from resources in Properties object (writing code for same). Constants definitely consume memory.
It is very easy to put all configuration constants in a class
column2: then refer to them throughout the app.

column1: To change the static configuration constants you modify the source and recompile.

column2: your program needs maintain more than one configuration
column3: or to alternate between configurations as it processes different files
column4: or even runs one thread with one configuration and another thread with a different configuration. You won’t be able to use that technique.

column1: The eaysiest way to hide a key or a value is to create a key/value having '\0' inside of the name. You can do this wth respect of the native functions NtCreateKey (see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff556468.aspx) NtSetValueKey (see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff557688.aspx) which use UNICODE_STRING as parameters instead of LPCTSTR. You can read more about usage of native registry API in http://www.codeproject.com/kb/system/NtRegistry.aspx for example. A Delphi code you will find here http://www.delphi3000.com/articles/article_3539.asp.

UPDATED: Because many people read this question I want to add some words to my answer. I want divide the part of the question which we can read also in the title "best place to hide a key in the Windows Registry" from the subject with license keys. Because I read some answers (written before me) which concerned almost only the part of license keys and read practically no answer on the question from the title I wrote me answer.
The subject with license key I find very complex. It depends on the licensing model choosed. It's important how to generate
column2: to distribute (to install) and to verify the key. Is key should be hardware depended or not? It can be one per computer or one per computer group. The key generation
column3: key installation or key verification can be either with respect of some online services (also from the internet) or without there. I can continue... There are a lot of aspects
column4: advantages and disadvantages of different approaches.

column1: So I decide to answer only on the main question from the title which is clear and have a separate interest. All other questions about license key should be discussed in my opinion in the separate question after clearing all requirements.

UPDATED 2 based on the updated question: It seems to me in your case would be better to use some scenario based on cryptographic signing of an activation ticket. For example the schema can looks like following:

• You software installed on the client computer will need an activation. Before activation it can not work or work in very restricted form (for example only some menus needed for software activation are enabled).
• You write a server component which will be used by client during the activation to generate the license key based of the activation request received from the client.
• If a client pay for the software you include the information about the client's "machine ID" (in any form which you want) in the database on the server.

<li>After starting of the activation process from the client software (either at the program start of from menu or in any other way like you want) it collects some information about the computer like computer name ("machine ID")
column2: some serial numbers or some other information about hardware or operation system which can not be changed without a new activation. This information the software send to your server (it is the activation request).

column1: <li>The server verify that the the client with the "machine ID" payed for the software and is not yet activated. Then the server calculate the hash (SHA1
column2: MD5 or some other) from the information send from the client and sign the respond with the server's private key (or servers certificate). The signed ticket server will be send back to the client. This ticket will play the role of licence key.

column1: <li>The server can add any additional information to the ticket before signing. For example it can add the information about the date till one the software should be valid (for example
column2: current day plus one year). So the ticket which will be send back to the client can contain the hash of input activation information and any additional information
column3: all what you want. Important is only that the information should be signed. In general you can include full client's request as clear text in the servers ticket instead of including of the hash
column4: but the usage of the hash a) reduce the ticket size and b) makes the ticket a little more secure.

column1: • Every client have public key corresponds to the private key used by server for signing of the activation ticket. The client save the ticket received from the server during activation in any place in registry of in the file system.

<li>Every next time if the client software will be started the software will read the saved activation ticket from the registry (or from the file system). Then the software collect the same information
column2: which are used for generation of the activation ticket
column3: calculate the hash and compare it with the hash from the saved ticket. It verify of cause the signature of the ticket with respect of the public key (or with respect of the server's certificate). Moreover the software can verify any other additional policy information from the ticket like the time till one the ticket is valid.

column1: All written is a roughly schema only
column2: but it is very simple and it is extensible. You need only study how use some simple cryptographic operation and implement there in your software.

column1: As a option you can don't have a server online
column2: but instead of that implement in the software (in menu for example) a possibility to generate the activation request and send it per email for example. Then you can offline (!!!) generate an activation ticket based of the server request and send the ticket back to the client also per email. A simple Reg-file which can be imported by double-click or some other simple import possibility in your software (cut & paste in the activation dialog) can end the process of the software activation.

column2: it sounds like you're interested in using Spring Roo to generate your data model code — but don't want (or need) any of Spring Roo's web controller code. If that's the case then you can separate your project into two modules:

column1: • A module containing model and persistence code that is created by Spring Roo
• A GWT web application that you create by hand.

Make the first (Roo) module a dependency of the second (GWT) module. Basically you're using Roo to create a JAR library that's used by your web application. As long as you don't run the controller command the Roo won't add any web application code to your module.

column2: for handling a data model
column3: there are two major design patterns: Dependency Injection and Singleton.

column1: Dependency Injection relies on passing the data model object from view controller to view controller as needed. Marcus Zarra (author of Core Data: Apple's API for Persisting Data on Mac OS X which I recommend) wrote a good article explaining Dependency Injection. Most of the Apple documentation recommends that you use the Dependency Injection design.
I like the Singleton pattern but it is very
column2: very
column3: very dangerous for a novice to use. The Singleton pattern is so easy to do wrong that most graybeards have given up on it and simply advise novices to never use it.

column1: The Singleton pattern has the advantage of increasing modularity and flexibility of the app. However
column2: it requires that you have a firm idea of what the data model will do before you start coding both the Data Model and the UI. It requires more work up front to get correct and it is not as forgiving as Dependency Injection. You have to use singletons with greater discipline.

column1: For a simple app with three hierarchal views
column2: Dependency Injection is the simplest and cleanest design to implement. You won't need the flexibility of a singleton and a singleton will just add unneeded complexity. The Navigation-based template with Core Data provided by Xcode will give you 50% of the app to start. Just add the second and third tier views and you're done.

The iPhone UI is so small and crowded that you are usually better off creating a different view/view-controller pair for different UIs. Hiding UI elements leaves gaps that are very noticeable and manually rearranging the UI elements on the fly is a pain.

column2: different views communicate to the user that the app is in a different state. You don't want the app to switch to a different state without informing the user. It's hard enough for them to understand what is going on without confusing them with UI slight of hand.

column1: It is very bad UI design to have the same user action present a different UI for no reason discernible to the user. For example
column2: presenting a "a uiwebview at even hours and a form on odd hours" would be a fantastically bad idea because the user would have no idea why clicking on a specific button sometimes gets them a web view and a form view other times. Do you expect the user to check the clock before clicking so that they know what to expect?

column1: If some UI element is unavailable for some reason e.g. no network access
column2: then it's better UI design to present the element as disabled instead of disappearing it. The interface grammar teaches users that grayed out controls are temporarily unavailable. That is much less confusing that a constantly changing UI.

You can't create a static unit of work
column2: because by definition a unit of work is a short lived object. Because the EF ObjectContext is designed around the unit of work pattern it is a bad idea to have a single ObjectContext instance during the life time of the application. There are several reasons for this.
the ObjectContext class is not thread-safe. This means that during the unit of work of one user (in a web app for instance)
column3: another user can commit his unit of work. When they share the same ObjectContext
column4: it means that in that situation just half of the changes are persisted and changes are not transactional. When you are lucky the ObjectContext fails and throws an exception. When you are unlucky
column5: you corrupt the ObjectContext and safe and load crap from and to your database and find out when your application is running in production (of course
column6: during testing and staging everything always seems to work).

column2: the ObjectContext has a caching mechanism that is designed for it to be short lived. When an entity is retrieved from the database it stays in the ObjectContext’s cache until that instance is garbage collected. When you keep that instance alive for a long period of time
column3: entities get stale. Especially if that particular ObjectContext instance is not the only one writing to that database.

column1: A HBox is just a box with a horizontal layout of children - it doesn't actually have vertical lines running between those children
column2: so you're not going to be able to use borders or anything on the HBox.

column1: Your best bet is probably adding VRule components in between each child component
column2: something like:

column1: You can adjust the VRule and HBox border styles to be consistent however you like. The only other options I can think of are to put borders around each child component with no border on the HBox (may need child padding depending on your components)
column2: embed all your components in Box components within the HBox like you suggest
column3: or doing something completely crazy like using a HorizontalList and embedding your components in a custom item renderer that is a consistent size with a border.

column1: Personally I'd just use VRule separators and move on. I'd rather double up on children than have all my components of interest one family level deeper in the HBox. If you need to generate your HBox children from a variable array or suchlike
column2: then you may want to put each one in a Box and use a Repeater or something. Some more detail would help for more specific answers.

column1: The LIKE operator does a pattern matching comparison. The operand to the right of the LIKE operator contains the pattern and the left hand operand contains the string to match against the pattern. A percent symbol ("%") in the LIKE pattern matches any sequence of zero or more characters in the string. An underscore ("_") in the LIKE pattern matches any single character in the string. Any other character matches itself or its lower/upper case equivalent (i.e. case-insensitive matching).

column2: my approach towards this (is heavily biased on the GOOS book that I just read

column1: • Create an interface to abstract away the file system from your code. Mock it where this class is needed as a collaborator/dependency. This keeps your unit-tests quick and feedback fast.

• Create integration tests that test the actual implementation of the interface. i.e. verify that calling Save() actually persists a file to disk and has the write contents (use a reference file or parse it for a few things that it should contain)

• Create an acceptance test that tests the whole system - end to end. Here you may just verify that a file is created - the intent of this test is to confirm if the real implementation is wired / plugged in correctly.

column1: The BASE acronym was defined by Eric Brewer
column2: who is also known for formulating the CAP theorem.

column1: The CAP theorem states that a distributed computer system cannot guarantee all of the following three properties at the same time:
A BASE system gives up on consistency.
• Basically available indicates that the system does guarantee availability
column2: in terms of the CAP theorem.

column1: • Soft state indicates that the state of the system may change over time
column2: even without input. This is because of the eventual consistency model.

column1: • Eventual consistency indicates that the system will become consistent over time
column2: given that the system doesn't receive input during that time.

column1: Brewer does admit that the acronym is contrived:
I came up with [the BASE] acronym with my students in their office earlier that year. I agree it is contrived a bit
column2: but so is "ACID" -- much more than people realize
column3: so we figured it was good enough.

column1: That depends.. RFID is a very broad field.
There are very simple tags that really only send back their ID when activated using a fixed function logic. I doubt many of them are still in use.
And then there are very sophisticated ones that even run programs written in JAVA and have crypto-processors and other funky stuff built in.
One example of this is the SmartMX Mifare card from NXP.
Note: Don't confuse active and passive tags with processor/no processor tags. A tag is active if it has it's own power supply. That does not imply that it has a processor and vice versa.

column2: but contain not so few examples of bad practices. Long and complicated methods
